unnormalised: Okay, so you wanna know about Indian Airways, huh? Well, buckle up, because it's a bit of a rollercoaster, just like trying to get a decent chai at Delhi airport for Rs. 20.

unnormalised: First off, forget about flying at the time you expect. Delays are practically a national pastime. If your flight is scheduled for 6:00 AM, mentally prep yourself for a 7:30 AM departure, maybe even later. I've been stuck at Bangalore airport for 4 hrs waiting for a flight to Mumbai thanks to "operational issues". Don't even get me STARTED on monsoon season. Flights get cancelled left and right, it's a total mess!

Flights get cancelled left and right, it's a total mess!

unnormalised: Then there's the whole issue of baggage. Make sure you stick to the weight limits, or else be ready to pay some serious dough. They're strict about that 15 kg check-in baggage allowance and 7 kg cabin baggage limit, trust me. I saw this aunty arguing with the IndiGo staff over 2 kg of extra baggage, and it was a whole scene. You're better off buying an extra bag in Sarojini Nagar for ₹300 and just checking that in!

unnormalised: But, to be fair, some Indian airlines are stepping up their game. Air India, under Tata, is trying to improve its service and fleet. They're adding new routes, like direct flights from Kochi to Dubai, and are trying to get rid of those ancient planes that feel like they're held together by duct tape and prayer. SpiceJet sometimes has ridiculously cheap fares, like Rs. 999 for a domestic flight (if you book way in advance and travel at 2 AM, maybe), and Vistara offers a slightly more premium experience.

SpiceJet sometimes has ridiculously cheap fares, like rupee nine hundred and ninety nine for a domestic flight (if you book way in advance and travel at two a m, maybe), and Vistara offers a slightly more premium experience.

unnormalised: And let's not forget the food. Airline food, in general, gets a bad rap, but Indian airlines often offer decent vegetarian options, which is a huge plus for many of us. You might get some passable dal chawal or a soggy samosa, but hey, it's better than nothing, right? Plus, you can always sneak in some homemade theplas or khakras from your mom's kitchen – they won't mind (much). My mom always packs me a HUGE dabba of food if I'm flying anywhere. It weighs at least 3 kgs, but it's worth it!

unnormalised: Pro-tip: Always, ALWAYS check the airline's website for the latest updates and travel advisories. Things change faster than the price of gold these days. And download their app – it's usually the easiest way to check your flight status and get boarding passes. Save yourself the stress of standing in line at the check-in counter. Also, remember to carry your Aadhar card with you, its required for Identity verification

unnormalised: Despite the occasional hiccups, flying within India is generally safe and convenient. Just be prepared for the unexpected, pack your patience, and maybe bring a good book or download some Bollywood movies to keep yourself entertained during those inevitable delays. And for the love of God, don't forget your charger. There's nothing worse than a dead phone when you're stuck at the airport for hours. I learned this the hard way back in 2017. Never again!
